posts.name: Big Apple Inn
posts.note: The Big Apple Inn is an institution of old-school Southern sandwiches from Jackson, MS, which have 'smokes' (sausage), 'ears' (pig ears), and tamales along with a whole lot of history and hospitality. The sausage sandwich and the pig sandwich were great and one of the best things I ate on my 13-day tour of the south. NOTE: They have multiple locations.
posts.rcmmnd: Anthony Bourdain and John T Edge

posts.name: Bully’s Restaurant
posts.note: Bully’s Restaurant is a venerable, unpretentious eatery dishing out soul food such as beef ribs, fried chicken, and catfish. Make sure to get yourself some greens. Recommended by John T. Edge.

posts.name: City Grocery
posts.note: City Grocery is fine Southern dining in a historical, two-story building with exposed brick, pine floors, and upstairs bar. City Grocery has become a landmark in the Oxford dining scene. Exposed brick walls and heart pine plank floor augment the candlelight and white linen staging some of the most inventive and exciting food in the South. Their (dishes) deft presentation is imaginative, skillful and disciplined, elevating them above qualification as regional and ethnic cuisine. Enjoy fine dining with family and friends.

posts.name: Doe's Eat Place
posts.note: Doe's Eat Place makes all beef tamales from Doe's original recipe. Made the same way since 1941, they are an authentic taste of the Mississippi Delta.

posts.name: Latham's Hamburger Inn
posts.note: Latham's Hamburger Inn is a great, tiny burger shop. The type of burgers they serve is called 'slugburgers'. Don't let the name scare you; there are no slugs. According to Wikipedia, a slugburger is unique to the NE Mississippi area, consisting of a patty made from a mixture of beef or pork and an inexpensive extender such as soybeans, it is deep fried in oil.

posts.name: Mayflower Cafe
posts.note: Mayflower Cafe is a landmark eatery dating to 1935 featuring Greek-inspired seafood and steak dishes in retro digs. The Mayflower began as a hamburger stand, started by a pair of Greek immigrants and friends from the deeply-Orthodox island of Patmos.

posts.name: Phillips Grocery
posts.note: Phillips Grocery is an out-of-the-way place is worth a stop. It's several blocks east of the downtown square of Holly Springs. If you get lost, that's okay; there are all kinds of interesting architecture to see in the neighborhoods of Holly Springs. Phillips Grocery is staffed with the friendliest staff but the burgers are excellent, and the historical atmosphere is worth a stop. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Snackbar
posts.note: Snackbar is a stylish bistro and oyster bar offering Southern-influenced French eats, that also serves cocktails and has live music. From a website posting about Snackbar, 'We’ve married French Bistro with North Mississippi Cafe resulting in the Bubba Brasserie cuisine. The Big Bad Smokehouse pulls double duty creating the items for our charcuterie program, and choucroute garni gets a second chance with collards and pickled peaches. Raw oysters arrive daily from all over the country, adding a unique touch to the glass tiled oyster bar that anchors our lower dining room. Top shelf whiskies and an extensive glass wine program round out an inviting and cozy bar setting likened to an “English Hunt Club.” We’ve got live music and late-night to keep you entertained. Chef Vishwesh Bhatt won the 2019 James Beard Award as Best Chef-South.' From the Eater website, 'Currently the most bustling of John Currence's restaurants, Snackbar is a bistro that blends the cooking of France, the deep South and, thanks to chef Vishwesh Bhatt, India. Expect everything from fried boudin balls to salmon tikka.'
posts.rcmmnd: Southern Foodways Alliance and John T Edge

posts.name: Rusty’s Riverfront Grill
posts.note: Rusty’s Riverfront Grill is a lively, family-friendly seafood restaurant and bar in saloon-like digs with warm woods, TVs, and a patio. Order the double fried green tomatoes or the blackened redfish with crayfish cream sauce.

posts.name: Taylor Grocery
posts.note: From Eater's website, 'Taylor Grocery is a space dating back to the late 1800s, Taylor is now in the hands of Lynn and Debbie Hewlett, who make some of the best catfish in the South.' Helen Rosner, like everyone else online, recommends getting the fried catfish.
